field_label:
Scoring Instructions:

0-25 dB=Normal hearing
26-40 dB=Mild hearing loss
41-55 dB=Moderate hearing loss
56-70 dB=Moderately severe hearing loss
71-90 dB=Severe hearing loss
91+ dB=Profound hearing loss

field_label: Does the patient have a Cholesteatoma?

select_choices_or_calculations: 1, Congenital | 2, Unclassifiable | 3, Pars tensa | 4, Pars flaccida | 5, Combination of pars flaccida and pars tensa | 6, Secondary to TM perforation | 7, Following trauma or iatrogenic
1, Recurrent | 2, Residual
1, S1 Protympanum | 2, S2 Sinus Tympani | 3, T Meso/Hypo-Tympanum | 4, A Epitympanum | 5, Ma Antrum | 6, Mc Mastoid cells
field_note: In order to simplify the extent of cholesteatoma, the middle ear and mastoid space is divided into four sites: the difficult access sites (S) includes S1, the supratubal recess (also called the anterior epitympanum or protympanum) and S2, which includes the sinus tympani and other recesses medial to the facial nerve in the retrotympanum. The posterior border of the attic is the posterior end of the incus short process or the fossa incudis. The mastoid includes the antrum and the mastoid cells.

select_choices_or_calculations: 1, facial palsy | 2, labyrinthine fistula | 3, canal wall destruction | 4, destruction of the tegmen | 5, adhesive otitis | 6, neck abscess
field_note: Cholesteatoma with extracranial complications or pathologic conditions including:facial palsy (FP), labyrinthine fistula (LF): with conditions at risk of membranous labyrinth, labyrinthitis, canal wall destruction (CW): more than half length of the bony ear canal, destruction of the tegmen (TD): with a defect that requires surgical repair, adhesive otitis (AO): total adhesion of the pars tensa, postauricular abscess or fistula, zygomatic abscess, neck abscess (NA).

select_choices_or_calculations: 1, S1  Primary (first surgery) | 2, S2p  Planned subsequent procedure | 3, S2r  Revision (i.e. unplanned) procedure
field_note: S1 signifies the first surgery for the condition being treated (eg first operation for cholesteatoma after a previous TM perforation repair). S2 signifies any subsequent surgery for that condition, not the number of operations completed (eg third surgery for a recurrence of cholesteatoma after two planned stages of surgery is coded as S2r)
For revision surgery, this is the nth operation

select_choices_or_calculations: 1, A1  Endoscopic transcanal (TEES) | 2, A2  Microscopic transcanal | 3, A3  Endaural | 4, A4  Post-auricular
field_note: If an incision is used for access to the mastoid, use of an endoscopic surgery is considered as an adjunct procedure (eg post auricular incision used for endoscopic access to the mastoid is A4 even if no microscope is used). If an external incision is made for harvest of a graft but not used for access to mastoid or middle ear, this is classified as A1 or A2. The term "permeatal approach" is considered to be synonymous with transcanal approach

select_choices_or_calculations: 0, Class 0 "None" Microscope only case | 1, Class 1 "Inspection only" Endoscope used to assess disease | 2, Class 2 "Mixed Dissection" Microscope and endoscope used for dissection | 3, Class 3 "Endoscope only" No use of microscope

0, Mx  No mastoid surgery | 1, Mu Previous mastoid surgery undisturbed | 2, M1a Canal wall preserved (aka cortical mastoidectomy) | 3, M1b  As M1a + posterior tympanotomy | 4, M2a  Only scutum removed (aka atticotomy) | 5, M2b  Scutum + posterosuperior wall removed (aka atticoantrostomy) | 6, M2c  Whole canal wall removed (eg modified radical mastoidectomy) | 7, M1a + M2a  Scutum removal + cortical mastoidectomy | 8, M1b + M2a  As above with posterior tympanotomy | 9, M3a  Subtotal petrosectomy, otic capsule preserved | 10, M3b  Subtotal petrosectomy + removal otic capsule
field_note: Mx means no mastoid surgery now or previously. Mu means that previous surgery to the mastoid was not revised at this operation.M1 procedure is a mastoidectomy leaving the canal wall intact (preserved), M2 is a mastoidectomy with removal of the canal wall partly or completely. M2a: as part of the canal wall is removed with removal of the scutum (atticotomy), this procedure is categorised in SAMEO-ATO with other "canal wall down" surgeries. However, many surgeons incorporate an atticotomy and scutum reconstruction with a cortical mastoidectomy in what is considered "canal wall up" surgery. This hybrid procedure is defined in SAMEO-ATO by combining the Mastoid codes for cortical mastoidectomy and scutum removal (eg M1a,2a or M1b,2a if posterior tympanostomy included).Partial scutum removal in which the inferior margin of the scutum is preserved, so creating a window in the bony wall of the ear canal for access to epitympanum or mastoid is also to be classified as M2a.  M3a differs from M2c in that the cavity is closed off completely with ear canal closure (removal of all ear canal skin and TM) as well as blocking up of the tympanic opening of the Eustachian tube.

select_choices_or_calculations: 0, Ex  No reconstruction | 1, Eu Previous reconstruction undisturbed | 2, E1 Reconstruction with soft materials | 3, E2  Reconstruction with hard materials (+/- soft materials)
field_note: Different materials may be used to reconstruct the scutum and/or bony canal wall with the intention of leaving a ventilated attic and mastoid under the graft: E1, Soft tissues include fascia, perichondrium, pericranium, periosteum and some bio-engineered grafts (eg porcine collagen or cadaveric human skin derivatives); E2, Hard reconstruction includes cartilage, bone, or solid prosthetic materials (eg titanium, hydroxyapatite).

select_choices_or_calculations: 1, Fascia graft | 2, Pedicled fascia | 3, Bio-engineered graft | 4, Cartilage graft | 5, Original bony canal wall | 6, Cortical bone | 7, Hydoxyapatite | 8, Titanium | 9, Other
0, Ox  No obliteration | 1, Ou Previous obliteration undisturbed | 2, O1  Partial obliteration | 3, O2  Total obliteration
field_note: Ox means an empty air space is present behind the ear canal or in the cavity. Partial obliteration spares the attic cavity + part of mastoid cavity (ie just a reduction of the size of cavity). Total obliteration is complete obliteration of the whole mastoid AND attic cavity. Obliteration of the attic without obliteration of the mastoid is considered  O1.

select_choices_or_calculations: 1, N/A | 2, Palva | 3, Muscle | 4, Fascial-periosteal | 5, Mid-temporal flap | 6, Temporo-parietal fascial flap
1, Bone paste | 2, Bone chips | 3, Cartilage slices | 4, Hydoxyapatite/HA granules | 5, Bioglass | 6, Fat | 7, Other

0, Ax  No bone removed from ear canal | 1, A1  Widening of canal at annulus or scutum | 2, A2  Partial or circumferential widening of bony canal (aka canalplasty) | 3, A3  Total canalplasty with soft tissue grafting of exposed bone
field_note: The distinction between A2 and A3 is that in A3 there is an absence of meatal skin to line the ear canal, eg during surgery for medial canal fibrosis. This Access category has not been developed for congenital meatal atresia surgery.

select_choices_or_calculations: 0, Tx  No repair of tympanic membrane defect | 1, Tu Previous tympanic membrane surgery undisturbed | 2, Tn  Original tympanic membrane preserved | 3, T1  Supplement to intact tympanic membrane (eg cartilage reinforcement) | 4, T2  Partial tympanic membrane grafting | 5, T3  Subtotal / total tympanic membrane grafting
field_note: Tn TM Normal, No Need for surgery. Tx TM not normal but not repaired (eg: atelectatic TM elevated but not reconstructed; perforation present but surgeon chose not to repair; or, previous cartilage tympanoplasty). T3  Total perforation is defined as complete absence or removal of the TM and annulus.  Subtotal perforation is the absence of TM but the annulus is still preserved.

select_choices_or_calculations: 1, Fascia | 2, Perichondrium | 3, Cartilage | 4, Homograft TM/Drum | 5, Periosteum | 6, Bio-engineered graft | 7, Fat | 8, Other

1, Underlay | 2, Under drum over malleus handle | 3, Interlay (ie between layers of ear drum) | 4, Within perforation (eg butterfly graft of fat plug) | 5, Lateral graft (ie underlay but extends lateral to entire annulus) | 6, Overlay | 7, Other

0, Ox  Abnormal chain, No reconstruction | 1, Ou Previous ossicular surgery undisturbed | 2, On Intact chain preservation | 3, Osi  Incus to stapes superstructure | 4, Osm  Malleus to stapes superstructure | 5, Ost  TM to stapes superstructure | 6, Osd  TM directly on stapes superstructure (eg myringostapediopexy) | 7, Ofi  Incus to footplate | 8, Ofm  Malleus to footplate | 9, Oft  TM to footplate | 10, Ofd  TM directly on footplate | 11, Ovi  Incus to vestibule (eg stapedotomy) | 12, Ovm  Malleus to vestibule | 13, Ovt  TM to vestibule
field_note: On Normal ossicular chain. Ossicular repair Not Needed. Ox Ossicles not normal, but no ossiculoplasty performed. It should be noted that the ossiculoplasty diagrams are conceptual and not a surgical illustration of technique. The stapes superstructure is shown in faded outline (Ofm and Oft) to indicate that a reconstruction can be performed whether superstructure is absent or present. Categories of ossiculoplasty are defined by the furthest points of contact of the graft or prosthesis between these anatomical structures: (m) malleus handle, (t) tympanic membrane (TM), incus, (s) superstructure of stapes, (f) footplate of stapes, (v) vestibule, (d) direct coupling of TM without a graft or prosthesis (eg Osd is myringostapediopexy).  Regarding cartilage tympanoplasty with absent incus but intact stapes: Osd Flat cartilage graft used in TM reconstruction in contact with stapes (cartilage myringostapediopexy). Ost Shaped piece of cartilage placed as a bridge between stapes and TM. Placement of a silastic band around the stapes superstructure and the shaft of a total ossicular replacement prosthesis between footplate and TM is included within Oft and Ofm
